I agree that all the re-querying will get expensive. In fact running 
such =
an evolution, in the matter of computational effort, that would 
come as cl=
ose as exhaustive search, but I think there is something 
beatuful in the w=
ay it is done. The CPPN can be re-queried each N 
timesteps or when some cr=
iteria in the environment is met. 

You know, I actually changed my entire =
phylosophy about EC since your 
last paper about NS came out. I am about to=
 add dynamic re-quering to 
the CPPN->HyperNEAT substrates, while being in =
Novelty Search. 

I don't really have to say too much good words, but it is=
 obvious, NS 
avoids all deception and it reaches solutions that FS has no =
hope to 
reach. Great work, you people over there in the Eplex group! Cheer=
s 
to Ken, David, Joel and Jason! I am not a PhD or anything like that, 
I =
am just a bulgarian freelancer but I really admire what you have 
done in t=
his area. 

Peter 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanle=
y@...> wrote:
>
> Peter, I think re-querying the CPPN over time is a great =
idea.  
We've
> talked about it in our research group but we don't have any=
 ongoing
> projects with it, and I don't know of any.  The only downside is=
 
that
> all that querying will get expensive.  However, it's very 
interes=
ting
> because it means that the learning rules themselves become 
distribu=
ted
> in a pattern, and are "made up" by HyperNEAT rather than being
> pres=
elected by the experimenter.
> 
> The CPPN might also be able to output Heb=
bian parameters; although
> that is less groundbreaking, though it might wo=
rk well.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <pet=
ar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all, 
> > 
> > It is an interesting ide=
a to see what if the phenotypes produced 
by the 
> > CPPNs change over the=
ir lifetime. There are two approaches to 
this: the 
> > CPPN can output he=
bbian learning parameters to the connections or 
the 
> > CPPN can be re-qu=
eried every time step, so the connections will 
be 
> > basically different=
 every time, depending on the environment, 
which 
> > will be input to the=
 CPPN. 
> > Is there any ongoing research into this? 
> > 
> > Peter
